channel.title: Console vs. PC gaming
channel.description:
So, i'd really like to upgrade my existing game PC but for the kind of performance i want the cost is hard to swallow. Ideally, what i'd *like*, is some gargantuan core i7 overclocked 3-SLI setup with a huge HD monitor getting 100 frames / second on MW2 (which is all possible, according to Tom's Hardware).
But all my buddies say a console gives decent performance with decent graphics at maybe 1/3 the cost of a cheap PC, much less the monster i'm lusting after.
You guys have any advice?
Option A: i might not survive to see retirement anyway. Just buy the PC i want.
Option B: i'm not the King of France. Just get a new video card.
Option C: Yeah, pad controllers suck. Get over it and buy a console.

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: CTID
item.description:
I’ve always been an Nvidia fan, really, but as of late, ATi’s cards have kicked their asses. The only reason I wouldn’t get a GTX 480 is because of heat, size, and price. I don’t have that kind of money, or the money for a water kit so it doesn’t overheat. Hopefully they’ll come out with a more efficient cooler for it or something.

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: Texter
item.description:
CTID:

I do, as Door said. I’m also not biased toward any one company, as you clearly are.

I wouldn’t call replying to your lame remarks an act of fanboyism. A 5970 is a decent choice for high performance this year, but it stutters, has scaling issues, needs ATi’s own specific driver profiles with new games releases, whereas the GTX480 only got a bit hot on air with the old BIOS and is significantly better at DX11, i.e. future proof. I wouldn’t recommend a GTX470 or lower and haven’t gotten a GTX480 either because it’s a bit of a joke to pay that much for an incomplete GPU. Hopefully Q4 will show us more hassle free products from either team.

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: saivert
item.description:
Maxey:

Yeah, I’m not seeing myself playing Uncharted or Killzone on my PC anytime soon.

so what? your life doesn’t depend on being able to play those games.

If a game is only available for consoles I just don’t play the game. I’m not going to rush out and buy a XBOX 360 or a PS3. not now, not ever.

I’m a PC gamer dammit!

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: func_random
item.description:
Being a PC fag is hard. I’ll be talking to someone and they’ll ask what my gamertag/PSN is, and I have to say that I don’t have a console. They ask why, and I reply that I find it a waste of money to have either when my PC can run them with better graphics, mods, and mouse+keyboard controls. Then a crowd gathers and I’m called a cheater because I can’t play Halo without installing a mod, (I guess they confuse mods with hacks?) and I care more about a game’s graphics than gameplay, (Thief 2 and Half-Life anyone?) and I’m a pussy because it takes more skill to wheel a knob around a controller than use the platform that first-person shooters were designed for.

These people are the reason I play multiplayer solely on PC, because it seems as though there is an intelligence limiter when it comes to people you come into contact playing through Steam/Hamachi/other online thing. Sometimes it’s quite depressing to hear about some of the Live shit that happens.

tl;dr: Consolefags are from America, glorious PCfag master race are from Scandinavia.

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: CTID
item.description:
Texter:

You really don’t know much about videocards, do you?

I do, as Door said. I’m also not biased toward any one company, as you clearly are. I’m actually using a 9800 GT right now. But my next card is going to be an HD5770.

I’m aware that the GTX 480 is a GOOD card. But it’s still incredibly big, and runs very, very hot. Not everyone can afford a decent water kit for their computer. Then again, I doubt most people can afford the 480, either. And after looking at pictures, yes, the 5970 is slightly bigger. But it’s also a dual-GPU card. And it’s gotten higher benchmarks over the 480 in every one I’ve seen.

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: Door
item.description:
Idle, the 5970 takes up about 4 more watts than the 480. Under load, it takes about 26 less watts than the 480.
Idle, the 5970 is about 4 degrees Celsius less than the 480. Under load, it’s about 12 degrees less.

That’s just with the stock coolers though, the Toxic version remains at a very cool(compared to other high-end cards) 41 degrees Celsius above room temperature but sucks up a huge amount of power for it’s cooler.

He does know about video cards but a lot of results are over-exaggerated.

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: Texter
item.description:
Jeannotvb:

processor chips are supposed to become smaller, cooler and less energy demanding

No, transistors are supposed to do that so an equally performing processor will become smaller and cheaper to manufacture OR making a faster processor of the same size. Example: what Intel is doing with their HPC processor (failed Larrabee), is simply fitting a shitload of Pentiums on a chip the size of…a Pentium (with 15 years in between atm lol).

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming

The only problem with Nvidia is that they don’t follow the basic laws, processor chips are supposed to become smaller, cooler and less energy demanding. Not the other way around.

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: Texter
item.description:
Maxey:

Most PS3 and 360 games are rendered directly at 720p and in few cases 1080p.

Most of the big titles use upscaling from the lower 600s. GTAIV, Halo 3, Modern Warfare 1&2 are nice examples. You can’t really see the difference, but the hardware is very limited.

CTID:

And the GTX 480 is a god-awful GPU that runs at around 100 degrees Celcius.

On water it remains quite cool, but I’m not saying it’ll use less power lol. And it’s a brilliant GPU, that’s for sure. Just look at how it responds to overclocking.

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: Jeannotvb
item.description:
CTID:

And the GTX 480 is a god-awful GPU that runs at around 100 degrees Celcius.

So does my GTX285, my 9800GX2 and my 7900GT - it happens when you keep the fanspeed on auto. Just crank it up to 100% and it should stay around 60-70 C max.

Although ATI has the edge at the moment, NVIDIA still has the fastest single core GPU, which is important for me because I absolutely hate any dual GPU setup (microstuttering issues, mobo overheating etc.).

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: CTID
item.description:
And the GTX 480 is a god-awful GPU that runs at around 100 degrees Celcius.

Read full topic

item.title: Console vs. PC gaming
item.dc:creator: Maxey
item.description:
Texter:

An i7 930 clocked to 4 GHz with a single GTX480 on water at 900 MHz will get you far today and even tomorrow. Game developers are getting better and better at getting the most out of the consoles, but realistically, we’re talking 2005 spec hardware, rendering at minimal resolutions upscaled to HD, at a mere 30 fps.

Most PS3 and 360 games are rendered directly at 720p and in few cases 1080p.

Maybe you’re referring to 1080i upscaling?

Read full topic
